awd_titl_txt: A New Approach for Experimental Study of Fundamental Combustion Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Combustion processes are the foundation of the electric power, transportation, and manufacturing infrastructures in the world. Transitions to new fuel feed stocks and transitions to new engines technologies pose challenges and opportunities to use the fuel properties to improve the combustion applications. This project focuses on experimental studies to identify and quantify fuel reaction chemistry important to successfully integrating new fuels and new engine designs. Pioneering new methods will be developed to isolate fuel chemistry that has not been previously studied. This fuel chemistry remains undiscovered country not due to lack of impact or significance, but due to the lack of experimental protocols and facilities.  

A technical approach has been designed based on the unique chemical reactor facility (a rapid compression facility, RCF) to isolate fuel reaction chemistry at the particularly challenging conditions required by modern and next-generation combustion systems. The RCF will be used to heat fuel mixtures to temperatures from 600 to 1200 K and pressures from 3 to 30 atm. Fast sampling will be used to acquire small amounts of the gases created while the fuel reacts at these high temperatures and pressures. The gas samples will be analyzed to identify the compounds present and the amounts of each compound as a function of time. From these data, the reaction pathways important to fuel combustion will be determined at relevant conditions. By strategically choosing the cases to demonstrate the approach, the experiments are designed to be extrapolated to similar fuels with high confidence. The project will also set precedence for other research teams to extend the experimental methods to broader classes of fuel compounds, thus benefiting conventional and unconventional fossil fuels as well as first and later generation biofuels.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Gas-phase chemistry plays an important role in many engineered and naturally-occurring systems. While much has been learned and is known regarding high-temperature oxidation of gases (e.g., combustion at temperatures above 1500 K), the fundamental mechanisms for gas-phase reactions at moderate temperatures (e.g., below 1200 K) remains largely unexplored. There are many processes that operate at moderate temperatures where the chemistry becomes rate limiting, e.g., directly affecting conversion rates and efficiencies, including many processes important for the carbon-neutral heat and power systems (e.g., utilization of biogas and other sustainable fuels). This project focused on demonstrating a new experimental method for quantifying the reactivity and reaction pathways important during thermal decomposition of the important alcohol propanol. The study successfully demonstrated the use of rapid compression of gas-phase mixtures as a means to study fundamental gas-phase chemistry where characteristic reaction times are on the order of 1 to 100 ms. Propanol dilute in an inert carrier gas was used for the case study. The results were used to identify and quantify the reaction pathways and rates of species consumption and production for a broad range of state conditions (i.e., temperatures and pressures). The data are the first of their kind and show new insights into the reaction chemistry of propanol, including where theory agreed well with the experimental results and where there were significant discrepancies. The outcomes include the technical approach ? i.e, showing how the methods can be applied to other key compounds important to the energy and industrial sectors, and the specific data are the basis for developing revised theory to improve predictive accuracy of gas-phase chemistry.

The outcomes of the project also include significant development of professional skills, expertise and resources. Undergraduate students who participated in the project continued to graduate school studies. Several women became credentialed experts due, in part, to participation in the project. Experimental resources were expanded at the University of Michigan (UM) supporting this project and other UM researchers and projects. The study also sets precedence for other researchers working in the area of advancing understanding of fundamental gas-phase chemistry.

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2022
Modified by: Margaret S Wooldridge

Image
  • Comparison of the effects of temperature on experimental data and model predictions for propanol decomposition and product species. The results highlight where theory is well validated and where discrepancies remain.
    Miles Burnett and Margaret Wooldridge
    Copyrighted
    Margaret S Wooldridge
    Outcomes of the pyrolysis study of 2-propanol
